document: Introduction to Database Management Systems (DBMS), including concepts such as data models, data independence, transactions, concurrency control, and DBMS architecture.

questions.question: A Database Management System is a software package used to store and manage databases.
A DBMS is designed to manage only small amounts of data efficiently.
DBMS supports concurrent access to data by multiple users.
In file-based systems, handling concurrency is simple and error-free.
An online bookseller database may contain customer data, order history, and book information.
Persistent data exists only while a program is running.
Relational databases organize data in the form of tables.
Oracle, IBM, and Microsoft are examples of DBMS vendors.
SQL is considered a data definition and data manipulation language.
The external level of abstraction describes how data is physically stored.
Data independence allows schema changes at one level without affecting other levels.
Physical data independence allows changes to storage structures without changing logical schemas.
Logical data independence deals with changes in physical storage devices.
Concurrency control is needed to prevent data inconsistency in multi-user environments.
A transaction is an atomic sequence of database operations.
A transaction can leave the database in an inconsistent state if it completes successfully.
Write-Ahead Logging helps ensure atomicity and recovery after system crashes.
A Database Administrator is responsible for security, schema design, and recovery.
A DBMS layered architecture includes components such as buffer management and query execution.
One major benefit of a DBMS is reduced data integrity and security.
